articles.title: Awesome Git Aliases
articles.description: Wouldn't it be awesome if Git could do more? What if you could customize it with your own commands, making it do anything you can imagine?

articles.title: Are You a Developer?
articles.description: If you’ve ever felt uneasy using the label “developer” to talk about yourself, this article is for you.

articles.title: Stop Installing Packages Globally
articles.description: I’m going to show you three different approaches you can use to run NPM package binaries without installing them globally.

articles.title: In Defense of Full-Stack Developers
articles.description: There’s a strong case to be made for someone who works on all parts of an application.

articles.title: I Made Lego Art!
articles.description: I decided to make art out of Legos. Here’s how I did it.

articles.title: 7 Insights From TEDxSeattle
articles.description: This past weekend I attended TEDxSeattle. Here are my favorite ideas from the conference.

articles.title: How to Be a Better Developer
articles.description: Lately I’ve had a few people ask me the same thing: “How can I become a good developer?” Unfortunately, that’s the wrong question to ask.

articles.title: Building a Killer iPhone Layout with CSS
articles.description: How to build an awesome iPhone layout with HTML and CSS.

articles.title: Crafting Twelve-Column Layouts with Flexbox
articles.description: I'll show you how to use flexbox to build twelve-column layouts, without the need for a library!

articles.title: Say Goodbye to Vendor Prefixes
articles.description: What if there were no vendor prefixes or browser inconsistencies, no external libraries and no compilers to deal with?

articles.title: Getting Dicey With Flexbox
articles.description: I'll walk you through the basics of flexbox by showing you how to build the faces of dice.

articles.title: Regular Expressions for the Rest of Us
articles.description: Here’s why you should take a second look at regular expressions, and how you can use them in the real world.

articles.title: Apocalyptic Zombies and Washing Machines: Lessons Learned From UX Launchpad
articles.description: Here are a few of my favorite lessons from UX Launchpad.

articles.title: The Difference Between Anchors, Inputs and Buttons
articles.description: I explain the difference between anchors, inputs and buttons and when and how to use each one.

articles.title: Why I Won't Sign Your NDA
articles.description: People often ask me to sign an NDA before they pitch me their start up ideas. I always say no. Here's why.

articles.title: Let's Write a RubyMotion App: Part 2
articles.description: In this tutorial, you'll build a painting application from scratch using RubyMotion. (Part 2)

articles.title: Let's Write a RubyMotion App: Part 1
articles.description: In this tutorial, you'll build a painting application from scratch using RubyMotion. (Part 1)

articles.title: Sass Color Variables That Don’t Suck
articles.description: I’ll show you a quick, easy method to wrangle your Sass color variables.

articles.title: Write Better JavaScript with Promises
articles.description: JavaScript promises—all the cool kids are using them. Let’s look at what promises are and how you can use them to write better code.

articles.title: 8 HTML Elements You're Not Using (and Should Be)
articles.description: Semantic markup helps people and machines understand content and its context. Let's take a look at eight HTML elements you can use today.

articles.title: Writing Better Media Queries with Sass
articles.description: Media queries are a pain, but they don't have to be. This article will show you a few Sass tricks you can use to simplify them.

articles.title: Writing an Awesome Build Script with Grunt
articles.description: In this guide, you'll learn to configure Grunt to build a modern web project.

articles.title: Partial Borders in CSS
articles.description: Have you ever wanted to create a border in CSS that only extends across part of an element? Here's a handy technique to achieve this effect using box shadows.

articles.title: Styling Autocompleted Inputs in Webkit
articles.description: You know you hate it—that ugly yellow background color in Webkit's autocompleted fields. Here's a nifty little trick you can use to change it in CSS.
